title: Elmore v. Elmore-Hill-McCreight Funeral Home
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Joann A. Elmore, Appellant,
v.
Elmore-Hill-McCreight Funeral Home, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-225
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Dana Allen Morris, of Camden, for Appellant.
George C. James, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this corporate freeze-out action, Joann Elmore appeals a Master-In-Equityâ€™s finding that the majority shareholdersâ€™ conduct was not oppressive or unfairly prejudicial towards her as a minority shareholder in a close corporation.Â  
Specifically, Mrs. Elmore asserts the majority shareholders in Elmore-Hill-McCreight Funeral Home, Inc. acted oppressively and/or unfairly prejudicial towards her as a minority shareholder by paying themselves salaries and dividends that exceed an amount commiserate with the duties they performed on behalf of the funeral home.Â  Based on this assertion, Mrs. Elmore sought, inter alia, an accounting and dissolution of the corporation or, in the alternative, an order requiring the funeral home to purchase her shares of stock.Â  We affirm.
â€œOur scope of review for a case heard by a Master-in-Equity who enters a final judgment is the same as that for review of a case heard by a circuit court without a jury.â€Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  This court may review the evidence to determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  See Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œWhile this permits us a broad scope of review, we do not disregard the findings of the Master, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.â€Â  Tiger, 301 S.C. at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 543.
After a thorough review of the record, we find no error in the Masterâ€™s ruling denying Mrs. Elmore her requested relief.Â  We base this decision on the evidence and testimony in the record and the following authorities: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-300 â€“ 310 (2006) (delineating grounds and procedures for judicial dissolution of a corporation); Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Systems & Services, Inc., 343 S.C. 587, 541 S.E.2d 257 (2001) (articulating that the definition of oppression is best left to judicial construction based on a case-by-case analysis of the fact-specific circumstances in each case).
AFFIRMED.[1]
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Van Osdell v. Graham
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte:
Van Osdell, Lester, Howe & Jordan, P.A., Respondent,
In Re: 
Brenda R. Babb, Appellant,
v.
Carey E. Graham, Southbridge, Cable Television, LLC. and Cable Plus of Carolina, Inc.,
Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-230
Submitted April 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Brenda R. Babb, of Calabash; for Appellant.
James B. Van Osdell and Cindy Graham Howe, of Myrtle Beach; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brenda R. Babb appeals a decision allowing Van Osdell, Lester, Howe & Jordan, P.A., (the Law Firm) to withdraw as her counsel.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On November 4, 1999, Babb hired the Law Firm to represent her at a series of shareholders meetings in an effort to resolve differences between Babb and Carey E. Graham.Â  Babb and Graham were shareholders in Cable Plus of Carolina, Inc., and members of Southbridge Cable Television, LLC.Â  After the negotiation efforts failed, the Law Firm filed a shareholderâ€™s derivative action on Babbâ€™s behalf on November 29, 2000, asserting causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, misappropriation of corporate opportunity, and breach of contract.
Babb also hired the Law Firm to represent her in an unrelated action that had been transferred to Charleston County and scheduled for a bench trial.Â  Immediately before the bench trial, Babb rejected a settlement offer from the opposing party and the bench trial proceeded in March 2004.Â  
On May 24, 2004, the Law Firm moved to be relieved as Babbâ€™s counsel in the present lawsuit.Â  In the motion, attorney James B. Van Osdell stated representation of Babb had become â€œunreasonably difficultâ€ either because Babbâ€™s objective in the litigation had changed from what he understood it to be when he agreed to represent her or because he no longer understood her objective.Â  Van Osdell further alleged it was unreasonably difficult to continue representing Babb because she was not in control of the case decisions even though she was the named plaintiff.Â  On the required motion cover sheet, the Law Firm requested a hearing and the presence of a court reporter.Â  While the motion was pending, the Law Firm continued to represent Babb zealously at depositions, motion hearings, and other matters in the underlying case.
The hearing was scheduled for July 29, 2004.Â  When Cynthia Graham Howe, another attorney in the Law Firm, appeared to argue the motion, she was advised that, at Babbâ€™s request, that the visiting judge assigned to the case would hear the matter in his chambers.Â  The attorney representing the opposing party in the underlying litigation consented to the motion and did not attend the hearing. 
When Babb arrived for the hearing, she presented copies to both Howe and the presiding judge of her memorandum in opposition to the Law Firmâ€™s motion.[2]Â  In her memorandum, Babb argued that allowing counsel to withdraw would be extremely prejudicial and detrimental to her and requested â€œlegal fees paid in this case be refunded.â€
At the conclusion of the hearing, the trial court granted the motion and requested Howe to prepare a proposed order.Â  The presiding judge also instructed Howe to send a copy of the order to Babb when the order was delivered to him.
Babb timely moved for reconsideration of the order granting the Law Firmâ€™s motion to be relieved as counsel.Â  On September 13, 2004, after the Law Firm filed an affidavit in opposition to Babbâ€™s motion and Babb responded to the affidavit, the trial court denied the motion without a hearing.Â  Babb received written entry of the order on September 15, 2004, and filed her notice of appeal on October 5, 2004.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We disagree with Babbâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in granting the Law Firmâ€™s motion to be relieved as her counsel.Â  
The South Carolina Rules of Professional Conduct permit a lawyer to withdraw from representing a client if â€œgood cause for withdrawal exists.â€[3]Â  â€œ[M]otions to withdraw [as counsel] must lie within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€[4]
In granting the motion, the court found the Law Firm gave sufficient reasons for withdrawing from the case, namely that (1) Van Osdell was unable to represent Babb competently and zealously because he did not understand her litigation objectives; and (2) the problem was compounded because Babb was not solely in control of her case and the litigation objectives were not necessarily hers.Â  Van Osdellâ€™s affidavit supports these findings.Â  Furthermore, Babb does not contest the finding in the appealed order that she â€œconceded that she confers with her husband . . . on all decisions concerning this litigation.â€Â  Under these circumstances, we see no reason to disturb the trial courtâ€™s decision to relieve the Law Firm as Babbâ€™s counsel.[5]  
2.Â  We decline to address Babbâ€™s argument that the trial court should have considered the prejudice to her resulting from the Law Firmâ€™s withdrawal in view of the duration of the case and the money she had already spent on legal fees.Â  The appealed order did not include a ruling on this argument.Â  Although Babb moved for reconsideration, she did not raise this issue in her motion.[6]
3.Â  We find no merit to Babbâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in declining to hear oral argument on her motion for reconsideration. Â Such motions â€œmay in the discretion of the court be determined on the briefs filed by the parties without oral argument.â€[7]
On appeal Babb argues the following reasons warranted oral argument on her motion:Â  (1) she did not receive a copy of the proposed order until after the trial court signed the final order relieving counsel; and (2) contrary to her understanding that the trial court would retain jurisdiction over the issue of legal fees in the underlying case, the order relieving counsel instructed the parties to consult the Fee Dispute Board for resolution of the matter.Â  
We disagree that these circumstances warranted oral argument on Babbâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  Regardless of any oral rulings by the trial court after hearing the Law Firmâ€™s motion to be relieved as counsel, the court had the prerogative to alter its decision pending entry of the signed written order by the clerk of court.[8]Â  We therefore hold the trial court acted within its discretion in refusing to hear oral argument on Babbâ€™s motion.
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Babb states in her brief on appeal that her memorandum was filed July 21, 2004; however, the filing date appearing on the motion included in the record is July 19, 2004.Â  Moreover, Babb notes she â€œprepared and offeredâ€ her memorandum, thus suggesting it was available at the hearing on July 19, 2004.
[3]Â  Appellate Court Rule 407, Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.16(b)(7); see also In re Anonymous Member of the Bar, 298 S.C. 239, 240, 379 S.E.2d 723, 723 (1989) (â€œWhen it is necessary to obtain the permission of the tribunal to withdraw from representation and the client will not consent, the attorney will usually have to establish good cause for withdrawal.â€).
[4]Â  Lucas v. State, 352 S.C. 1, 7, 572 S.E.2d 274, 277 (2002) (quoting In re Goodwin, 279 S.C. 274, 276-77, 305 S.E.2d 578, 579 (1983)).
[5]Â  See 7A C.J.S. Attorney & Client Â§ 268, at 297 (2004) (noting an attorney is usually justified in moving to withdraw from a case because of client conduct â€œtend[ing] . . . to destroy the reciprocal confidence required between attorney and clientâ€).
[6]Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule on a question and the appellant fails to move under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals and should not be addressed).
[7]Â  Rule 59(f), SCRCP.
[8]Â  See id. Rule 58(a) (â€œA judgment is effective only when so set forth and entered in the record.â€); Ford v. State Ethics Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 821, 823 (2001) (â€œUntil written and entered, the trial judge retains discretion to change his mind and amend his oral ruling accordingly.â€).

title: Lucas v. Vanover
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Don Lucas and Jean Lucas, Respondents,
v.
Glenn E. Vanover, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-233
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed April 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Holly Palmer Beeson, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Andrew Potter and Gary H. Johnson, II, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Don and Jean Lucas brought suit against Glenn Vanover for damages to their vehicle stemming from an automobile accident.Â  Vanover appeals the award, and contends the circuit court erred in admitting the vehicle ownerâ€™s testimony concerning the amount of damages, expert witness testimony concerning supplemental repair costs, and attorney statements from the accident report concerning the speeds of the vehicles.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
The Lucasesâ€™ vehicle was struck by Vanover when he crossed the center line of the roadway while under the influence of alcohol.Â  The Lucases filed a complaint seeking property damage against Vanover. Â Vanover appeared and filed an answer stipulating to his negligence and admitting fault.Â  Following an order granting summary judgment as to liability in favor of the Lucases, the circuit court held a damages hearing.Â  
At the hearing on damages, Mr. Lucas testified that his 2001 Chevrolet Impala 4-door sedan was â€œtotaledâ€ and that his wife had to be cut from the car.Â  Without objection, he testified to the negotiations he had with his insurance company to settle on the amount of damage.Â  As a result of these negotiations, the Lucases were paid $24,800 for the vehicle. Â In addition, Mr. Lucas testified that towing and storage fees were incurred in the amount of $385, but there was a salvage value of the vehicle of $2,650.Â  
To contest the amount of damages claimed by the Lucases, Vanover presented the testimony of David Holder, an expert appraiser, who opined that the car could have been repaired for approximately $11,338.Â  Holder opined that the car did not meet the threshold for a total loss.Â  Holder testified there may be supplements, meaning additional damage, discovered once repairs were initiated.Â  The Lucasesâ€™ counsel asked Holder whether the supplements could have added $7,000 to $10,000 to the repair bill, to which Holder replied, over Vanoverâ€™s objection, that his estimate of the supplements would be an additional $500 to $1,000. Â Finally, Holder acknowledged that he could not testify as to the extent of the diminution of value of the car, but admitted there would be diminished value to the relatively new car.Â  
At the conclusion of the hearing, the circuit court asked a series of questions, one of which was answered by the Lucasesâ€™ lawyer:Â  

Court:Â  How fast were the cars traveling?Â  
Counsel for the Lucases:Â  Judge, according to the wreck report - - 
Counsel for Vanover:Â  Your Honor, I would just object to that coming in.Â  Thereâ€™s no Trooper here to testify.Â  The parties did not testify about how fast - - 
Court:Â  They should have.Â  That goes directly to the amount of damage that was done to the car.Â  I think as the factfinder, Iâ€™m entitled â€“ really, I probably shouldâ€™ve asked them those questions when they were on the stand, but I didnâ€™t.Â  But Iâ€™m going to ask your expert a couple other questions too.Â  

After another objection, the circuit court added that â€œwhat heâ€™s going to tell me [concerning the speeds of the vehicles] is just to satisfy my curiosity.â€Â  The attorney answered the circuit courtâ€™s question:

Counsel for the Lucases:Â  Judge the wreck report indicates that our insured [the Lucases] was driving 50 miles an hour and the otherâ€”the defendant [Vanover], according to the wreck report, was doing 70, if Iâ€™m reading this correctly.

In its findings of fact, and during the hearing for the motion for reconsideration, the circuit court repeatedly stated that it had not given the speed of the vehicles any weight.
The circuit court determined the amount of damages to be $22,535.Â  Vanoverâ€™s motion to reconsider and alter or amend the judgment was subsequently denied.Â  This appeal centers around the evidence presented to support the circuit courtâ€™s determination of damages.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of evidence is within the circuit courtâ€™s discretion. Â R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 439, 540 S.E.2d 113, 121 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The courtâ€™s ruling to admit or exclude evidence will only be reversed if it constitutes an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law. Â Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002); see also Whaley v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 456, 483, 609 S.E.2d 286, 300 (2005) (observing admission of evidence
will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision will not be reversed on appeal unless it appears the court clearly abused its discretion and the objecting party was prejudiced by the decision. Â S.C. Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 524, 548 S.E.2d 880, 886 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                 
Total Loss 
Vanover contends the circuit court erred in allowing Lucas to testify as to the damage to the vehicle, specifically whether the vehicle was â€œtotaled,â€ when the matter required specific, technical and specialized knowledge to understand the evidence presented and because such testimony lies strictly within the province of an expert.[1]Â  We disagree.Â  
 It is well settled in South Carolina that an owner of property may testify concerning its value and damages.Â  See, e.g., Waites v. S.C. Windstorm & Hail Underwriting Assâ€™n, 279 S.C. 362, 366, 307 S.E.2d 223, 225 (1983) (stating that an owner may testify as to the extent of rain and windstorm damage); Hawkins v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 594-95, 493 S.E.2d 875, 880 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating an owner may testify to the diminished value of his real property for failure to develop a proposed road); Hill v. City of Hanahan, 281 S.C. 527, 531-32, 316 S.E.2d 681, 684 (Ct. App. 1984) (stating that an owner may testify as to the value of real property taken in a condemnation setting).Â  This is not only the accepted rule in South Carolina jurisprudence, but it is also contemplated under the rules of evidence.Â  Rule 701, SCRE, provides for opinions or inferences by a laymen which: â€œ(a) are rationally based on the perception of the witness, (b) are helpful to a clear understanding of the witnessâ€™ testimony or the determination of a fact in issue, and (c) do not require special knowledge, skill, experience or training.â€Â  Furthermore, â€œconclusions or opinions of laymen should be rejected only when they are superfluous in the sense that they will be of no value to the jury.â€Â  Small v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 468, 494 S.E.2d 835, 845 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
As the owner of the car, Mr. Lucas was qualified to testify concerning its value after the wreck.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion by admitting his testimony that the car was â€œtotaled.â€ 
II.              
Speculative Testimony of Expert Witness 
Vanover contends the circuit court erred in instructing Holder, his expert witness, to provide speculative testimony as to the supplemental repairs to the vehicle.Â  We disagree.Â  
The admission or exclusion of expert testimony is a matter within the sound discretion of the circuit court.Â  Fields v. Regional Medical Center Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Pike v. S.C. Dept. of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000).
Contrary to Vanoverâ€™s assertion, Holder never â€œspeculatedâ€ as to the costs of supplemental repairs; rather, Holder testified that supplemental repairs were likely.Â  He was qualified to provide an opinion regarding the initial costs of repairs, and was therefore able to provide an opinion regarding the likelihood additional repairs would be necessary.Â  
Moreover, when asked if those supplements could have added another $7,000 to $10,000 to the repair estimate, Holder stated that in his opinion, the supplements would have been limited to a range of $500 to $1,000 based upon his original appraisal.Â  This answer supported Vanoverâ€™s argument. Â Thus, even if we found error in the admission of the expertâ€™s opinion on the dollar amounts for the supplemental repairs, Vanover has failed to demonstrate any prejudice resulting from the admission. Â Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in allowing Holderâ€™s testimony regarding supplemental repairs.Â  Â 
III.          
Vehicle Speed 
Vanover contends the circuit court erred in permitting the Lucasesâ€™ attorney to respond to the courtâ€™s inquiry concerning the speeds of the vehicles at the time of the accident.Â  Specifically, Vanover relies on the proposition that under section 56-5-1290 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), no accident report â€œmay be evidence of the negligence or due care of either party at the trial of any action at law to recover damages.â€Â  We agree the information read from the accident report was inadmissible but find no reversible error.
Initially, we note that comments or arguments made by counsel are not evidence.Â  See McManus v. City of Greenwood, 171 S.C. 84, 89, 171 S.E.2d 473, 475 (1933) (holding statements of fact
appearing only in argument of counsel will not be considered as evidence); South Carolina Dept. of Transp. v. Thompson, 357 S.C. 101, 106, 590 S.E.2d 511, 513 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œArguments made by counsel are not evidence.â€).Â  Moreover, in Brown v. Allstate, our supreme court set forth the role of a circuit court sitting without a jury:Â  

According to the [lower court], if incompetent evidence is admitted on the ultimate issue of the trial, the trial judge must affirmatively reject this evidence, even if it is clear he is making a judgment based on competent evidence in the record. Â We reject this rule because it would require trial judges to rule on all admitted evidence in a bench trial. Â A trial judgeâ€™s role in a bench trial is to admit all evidence and then evaluate it in a non-jury setting. Â The [lower courtâ€™s] rule is, therefore, unnecessarily burdensome and would inhibit the trial judgeâ€™s ability to evaluate the evidence and ascertain the truth.

344 S.C. 21, 27, 542 S.E.2d 723, 726 (2001) (emphasis added).Â  
Therefore, under Brown v. Allstate, the role of the circuit court in this matter was to admit all evidence, admissible or inadmissible, and then evaluate it as the fact finder.Â  The Brown v. Allstate rule does not require the circuit court to make an affirmative statement that it did not rely on the incompetent evidence in rendering its decision.Â  Brown v. Allstate requires only that the circuit court reference the competent evidence it used in reaching its decision in its order.Â  
Here, the circuit court admitted all the evidence, competent and incompetent, introduced at the trial.Â  In its findings of fact, and during the hearing on the motion for reconsideration, the circuit court repeatedly stated that it had not given the speed of the vehicles any weight.Â  The order of the circuit court cited only the competent evidence it relied on in formulating the amount of damages, and under the principle established in Brown v. Allstate, it should be affirmed.
CONCLUSION
Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.Â  

[1] Vanover has cited no case to support his claim that declaring property a total loss is in the sole purview of expert testimony.Â

title: State v. Thomas
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
James Shawn Thomas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-234Â Â Â 
Submitted April 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 27, 2006 

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, and Harold W. Gowdy, III, Seventh Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  On April 11, 2005, James Thomas pleaded guilty to felony DUI resulting in death, felony DUI resulting in great bodily injury, and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent sentences of ten years in prison for each charge.Â  Thomas appeals, arguing his guilty plea failed to comply with the mandates set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  On appeal, counsel for Thomas has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), asserting that there are no meritorious grounds for appeal and requesting permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Thomas did not file a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: We Do Alterations, LLC v. Powell
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
We Do Alterations, LLC, Appellant,
v.
Nora Powell and Margaret Salinas, individually and d/b/a Margaretâ€™s Alterations,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master in Equity and Special Circuit Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-235
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bruce Robert Hoffman, of St. Helena Island, for Appellant.
Thomas Kemmerlin, Jr., of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  We Do Alterations, LLC (Appellant) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order reversing the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal, remanding the case to the magistrate for disposition of We Do Alterationsâ€™ motion to dismiss, and dismissing the case pending in circuit court.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
In November 2003, Appellant filed a breach of contract action in magistrateâ€™s court against Nora Powell and an interference with contract action against Margaretâ€™s Alterations (Respondents).[2] Respondents timely answered and counterclaimed for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Appellant then moved to dismiss the counterclaims under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, which the magistrate denied.Â  Thereafter, Respondents filed amended answers and counterclaims.[3] In July of 2004, Appellant requested the magistrate transfer or dismiss the cases because â€œPlaintiffâ€™s damages in both of the above matters well exceed[ed] the jurisdictional maximum of the Magistrateâ€™s Court, and Plaintiff [has] now filed a consolidated suit, against the same parties on the same grounds, as well as others, in the Court of Common Pleas.â€ One day after the filing of the motion, and without any notice to Respondents, the magistrate dismissed the cases.Â  Â 
Appellant then filed its consolidated complaint in circuit court.Â Â  Consequently, Respondents filed a notice of appeal from the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal, moved to dismiss the circuit court case, and requested an expedited hearing in magistrate court.Â  The magistrate submitted a return to the appeal, admitting error in dismissing the case based on Rule 41(a)(2), SCRCP, which specifically states that an action shall not be dismissed if a counterclaim has been pleaded prior to the service of a motion to dismiss.Â Â Â  The circuit court reversed the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal, remanded the case back to the magistrate, and dismissed the circuit court case.Â  The circuit court denied Appellantâ€™s motion for reconsideration. This appeal followed.Â Â Â 
           
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant claims the trial court erred in reversing the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal and remanding the case to the magistrate because Respondents can show no prejudice by the dismissal.Â  We disagree.
Rule 41, SCRCP, states 

(1) By Plaintiff; By Stipulation. . . . [A]n action may be dismissed by the plaintiff without order of court (A) by filing and serving a notice of dismissal at any time before service by the adverse party of an answer or motion for summary judgment, whichever first occurs, or (B) by filing a stipulation of dismissal signed by all parties who have appeared in the action. . . .
(2) By Order of Court.Â  Except as provided in paragraph (1) of this subdivision of this rule, an action shall not be dismissed at the plaintiffâ€™s instance save upon order of the court and upon such terms and conditions as the court deems proper.Â  If a counterclaim has been pleaded by a defendant prior to the service upon him of the plaintiffâ€™s motion to dismiss, the action shall not be dismissed against the defendantâ€™s objection unless the counterclaim can remain pending for independent adjudication by the court. . . . 

(emphasis added).Â  
Rule 41(a)(1) does not apply to this case because We Do Alterations filed the motion to dismiss after Respondents had already answered and counterclaimed. Â Furthermore, Respondents did not agree to the dismissal, as evidenced by their timely appeal.Â Â  Â Â 
Because Rule 41(a)(1) is inapplicable, plaintiffs may only dismiss a case pursuant to an order of the court, as dictated by Rule 41(a)(2).Â  Per Rule 41(a)(2), if a defendant has pled a counterclaim prior to the service upon him of the plaintiffâ€™s motion to dismiss, the magistrate may only grant the motion if the defendants do not object or the counterclaim can be independently adjudicated.Â  Respondents counterclaimed for attorneyâ€™s fees nearly eight months before Appellant filed its motion to dismiss, and the magistrate did not afford Respondents the opportunity to object. This, in itself is prejudicial to Respondents. Therefore, the magistrate erred in granting appellantâ€™s motion. Â Furthermore, Respondents timely filed a notice of appeal from the order of dismissal, and the magistrate admitted the error in his return to the appeal. Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s reversal of the order of dismissal and remand to the magistrate for reconsideration of Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Appellant also claims the trial court erred in dismissing the case pending in circuit court under Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP, because it did not serve the circuit court complaint on Respondents until after receiving notice of the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal.Â  We find no error. 
Â Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP, provides for dismissal of an action when another case is pending between the same parties for the same claim.Â  The trial court remanded the case to magistrate court for disposition of Appellantâ€™sâ€™ motion to transfer or dismiss because the order of dismissal violated Rule 41(a)(2).Â  This action required the trial court to then dismiss the pending circuit court case with the same claims.Â  See Rule 12(b)(8).Â  We find the trial court properly dismissed the circuit court case.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] The Beaufort magistrate court assigned the action against Nora Powell case number 302037 and the action against Margaretâ€™s Alterations case number 302038.Â  The cases were later dismissed per We Do Alterationsâ€™ motion and brought in circuit court as a consolidated case. Â Â For purposes of this appeal, the magistrate court cases will be discussed as one action.Â  
[3] We Do Alterations argues that Respondentsâ€™ amended answers and counterclaims were unauthorized pleadings because they were not filed with leave of the court or permission of We Do Alterations, as required by Rule 15, SCRCP.Â  However, We Do Alterations did not object to the filing, and even appeared to accept them in a handwritten note from counsel for We Do Alterations to Respondentsâ€™ counsel, stating â€œTom, I accept your apology, and likewise regret matters getting out of hand.â€ Nevertheless, We Do Alterationsâ€™ argument regarding the amended answers and counterclaims has no bearing on our decision because the original counterclaims suffice to engage the application of Rule 41(a)(2), SCRCP.Â
